title: How to Make Raspberry Coulis

steps.headline: Add the ingredients to a blender.
steps.description: You can also use a food processor. Add 10 ounces of raspberries, 2 tablespoons of sugar, and 1 teaspoon of lemon juice.

steps.headline: Blend the ingredients.
steps.description: Blend the ingredients until it is thoroughly puréed. This process should take a couple of minutes. Scrape down the sides of the blender or food processor as needed.

steps.headline: Strain the coulis.
steps.description: Strain out any pulp and seed pieces through a fine strainer. You can also use cheesecloth for this purpose. Place a bowl under the strainer or cheesecloth. Let the juice drain through. With a strainer, use the back of a spoon to press down on the pulp to help extract the juice below. With cheesecloth, squeeze the cloth with clean hands to release the juices.

steps.headline: Add the teaspoon of kirsch.
steps.description: Once you've strained the pulp out, add the liquor to the coulis. Stir it in. Kirsch is a brandy made from black morello cherry juice. You can also use any raspberry liquor, such as chambord. However, you can skip this step if you don't have anything appropriate on hand.

steps.headline: Store the coulis.
steps.description: One of the best ways to store coulis is a in a squeeze bottle, as it makes it easy to top desserts with a drizzle of the coulis. You can keep it in the fridge for about a week or in the freezer for several months.

steps.headline: Wash the raspberries.
steps.description: Run them under cool water to wash them, and then shake off any excess water.

steps.headline: Add the ingredients to a saucepan.
steps.description: Place the pound of raspberries, the 3/4 cup of sugar, and a tablespoon of lemon juice in the pan. Turn the heat to medium.

steps.headline: Simmer for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Let the mixture simmer for about 10 minutes. The sugar should dissolve by the time you are done.

steps.headline: Add sugar if it is not sweet enough.
steps.description: Taste the coulis, and add additional sugar if needed. Cook it until it dissolves.

steps.headline: Strain the coulis.
steps.description: Place a strainer over a bowl, and pour the coulis into the strainer. Push the pulp and seeds around to drain the sauce into the bowl below.

steps.headline: Taste again.
steps.description: Add an additional tablespoon of lemon juice if the coulis could use more zing.

steps.headline: Place the coulis in an airtight container.
steps.description: Store the container in the fridge.

methods.name: Creating Coeur a la Crème with Raspberry Coulis

steps.headline: Leave the cream cheese to soften.
steps.description: Leave the cream cheese on the counter for several hours before starting this recipe.

steps.headline: Place cheesecloth in a 6-ounce ramekin or mold.
steps.description: A heart mold works well for this recipe.

steps.headline: Whisk together the ingredients.
steps.description: Add the 4 ounces of cream cheese, 1/3 cup of yogurt, 4 teaspoons of sugar, 1 teaspoon lemon zest, 1/4 teaspoon lemon juice, 1/4 teaspoon vanilla, and a dash of salt to a bowl. Whisk the ingredients together until thoroughly combined.

steps.headline: Strain the mixture.
steps.description: Run the mixture through a clean strainer to remove any lemon pulp or big pieces of zest.

steps.headline: Spoon the mixture into the mold.
steps.description: Fill the mold with the mixture, and then cover it up with the cheesecloth. Set in the refrigerator for about 4 hours.

steps.headline: Remove the cheesecloth.
steps.description: Release the mold onto a plate, setting the coeur in the middle of the plate. Let it stand for about 20 minutes.

steps.headline: Add the raspberry coulis.
steps.description: Use the squeeze bottle to add a pool of coulis around the coeur. You can also drizzle it over the top. Garnish with a raspberry if desired.

methods.name: Making Lemon Pudding Cake with Raspberry Coulis

steps.headline: Turn the oven to 350 degrees Fahrenheit.
steps.description: Let it heat up while you are making the batter.

steps.headline: Mix the dry ingredients.
steps.description: In a large bowl, add the 1/4 cup of flour, the 1/2 teaspoon of salt, and 1/2 cup of sugar. Blend together.

steps.headline: Separate the eggs.
steps.description: Get out a medium bowl and a large bowl. Crack an egg down the middle over the large bowl, careful to keep the yolk in the shell. Pass the yolk back and forth between the two shells, letting the white drain out below. When you've removed all the egg white, dump the egg yolk in the other bowl. You can also use an egg separator. Do this process for all three eggs.

steps.headline: Zest and juice the lemon.
steps.description: Wash the lemon off in warm water, and then dry it. Use a zester to run around the outside of the lemon, grating the zest into the yolks. Avoid the white pith, as it is bitter. Once you've zested the lemon, juice it into a small bowl. Measure out 5 tablespoons, and add it to the yolks, as well. You may need to juice more than one lemon to get 5 tablespoons (73.9 ml).

steps.headline: Mix together the wet ingredients.
steps.description: To the egg yolk and lemon bowl, add the cup of milk. Use a whisk to thoroughly combine the ingredients.

steps.headline: Combine wet and dry.
steps.description: Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients. Stir until well incorporated.

steps.headline: Beat the egg whites.
steps.description: Use a hand mixer to beat the egg whites. Once you see soft peaks beginning to form, begin adding in the 1/4 cup sugar until you see stiff peaks. They should be glossy.

steps.headline: Add the egg whites to the batter.
steps.description: Pour in a quarter of the batter, and use a whisk to combine. Add the rest of the egg whites, but gently fold them in rather than whisking them in. To fold egg whites in, you gently cut them into the batter with a spoon, folding the batter over the egg whites and vice versa. Egg whites add lightness to baked goods, but they only work if you don't over stir them.

steps.headline: Spoon batter into a small baking dish.
steps.description: Grease a pan with oil or butter, and then spoon the batter in. Set the baking dish in another one with higher sides. Pull the oven rack partway out. Set the whole dish on the tray. Pour boiling water into the outer baking dish, so that it reaches the height of the batter on the inside.

steps.headline: Back until lightly browned.
steps.description: Leave the cake in the oven for 40 to 45 minutes. It should puff up while baking.

steps.headline: Remove the cake from the oven.
steps.description: Be careful of the hot water when removing the cake.

steps.headline: Serve warm.
steps.description: Serve the lemon cake warm with a drizzle of raspberry coulis.
